title: AI Comprehensive Exam Bank - Batch 1
description: Fundamental definitions, Intelligent Agents, Search Strategies, and Logic.

questions.question: In the context of self-driving cars, an AI approach concerned with making decisions closely like a human driver is an example of [___], while a recommendation system optimizing user satisfaction is an example of [___].
questions.explanation: Acting Humanly focuses on mimicry (Turing Test), while Acting Rationally focuses on achieving the best outcome (maximizing utility).

questions.question: The Turing Test measures intelligence as:
options: A machine's ability to detect a human's presence.
A human's ability to detect a machine's presence.
A human's inability to distinguish a machine from a human.
A machine's ability to solve complex mathematical proofs.
questions.explanation: If the interrogator cannot distinguish the machine from a human, the machine passes the test (Acting Humanly).

questions.question: In a robot designed to clean your house, which component of PEAS represents the rooms, furniture, and obstacles?
questions.explanation: The Environment is the physical world the agent operates in.

questions.question: If an Intelligent Agent is performing 'Autonomous Driving', its environment is best described as:
questions.explanation: Driving is Dynamic (world changes), Continuous (speed/steering are not discrete steps), and Partially Observable (blind spots).

questions.question: Which search algorithm requires the least amount of memory?
questions.explanation: DFS has linear space complexity O(bm), whereas BFS has exponential space complexity O(b^d).

questions.question: In the game tree of Chess, the Minimax algorithm is applied to:
options: Choose the move that minimizes the maximum possible loss.
Find the shortest path to the end of the game regardless of score.
Randomly select a move to confuse the opponent.
questions.explanation: Minimax assumes the opponent plays optimally to hurt you; you choose the move that gives the best result against their best counter-play.

questions.question: Predicting a student's mark as a percentage (e.g., 85.5%) is [___], while predicting a student's result as Pass/Fail is [___].
questions.explanation: Regression predicts continuous values (percentages); Classification predicts discrete categories (Pass/Fail).

questions.question: In Genetic Algorithms, the trade-off between Exploration and Exploitation is handled respectively by:
questions.explanation: Mutation introduces random changes (Exploration). Crossover combines known good traits (Exploitation).

questions.question: A heuristic function h(n) is considered 'Admissible' if:
options: It equals the true cost to the goal.
It never underestimates the cost to the goal.
It never overestimates the cost to the goal.
questions.explanation: Admissibility requires h(n) <= h*(n). It must be optimistic.

questions.question: Which data structure is used to store the fringe (frontier) nodes in Breadth-First Search (BFS)?
questions.explanation: BFS uses a FIFO Queue to explore level by level.

questions.question: Which type of learning involves an agent receiving rewards or penalties at the end of a sequence of steps?
questions.explanation: Reinforcement Learning is based on the reward/punishment mechanism.

questions.question: Which search algorithm is optimal and complete if the heuristic is consistent?
questions.explanation: A* is optimal and complete given an admissible (tree) or consistent (graph) heuristic.

questions.question: In the context of Big Data, 'Veracity' refers to:
options: The messiness or trustworthiness of the data.
questions.explanation: Veracity deals with the quality, accuracy, and uncertainty of data.

questions.question: Which technique is used to reduce the dimensionality of data?
questions.explanation: PCA is a classic dimensionality reduction technique.

questions.question: What is the 'Horizon Effect' in game playing AI?
options: When the game ends in a draw.
When the search space is too small.
When an inevitable bad event is pushed just beyond the search depth limit.
When the heuristic value is zero.
questions.explanation: The agent delays a loss to the next move beyond its lookahead, thinking it is safe.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a Horn Clause?
questions.explanation: A Horn clause has at most one positive literal. 'p -> ~q' is equivalent to '~p v ~q' (Horn). However, in many contexts of the uploaded exams, 'p -> ~q' is flagged because definite clauses usually imply a positive conclusion.

questions.question: The action 'STACK(A,B)' in a robot arm problem usually specifies:
options: Place block B on Block A
Place block A on Block B
questions.explanation: Standard STRIPS notation: Stack(x, y) puts x on top of y.

questions.question: Bagging (Bootstrap Aggregating) relies on which method?
questions.explanation: Bagging creates multiple datasets by resampling the original data with replacement.

questions.question: Object Detection involves:
options: Only assigning a label to the image.
questions.explanation: Detection identifies 'what' is where (classification + localization).

questions.question: Who is known as the 'Father of AI'?
questions.explanation: John McCarthy coined the term 'Artificial Intelligence' in 1956.

questions.question: Rational agents are designed to:
options: Maximize their performance measure given their knowledge.
Always succeed regardless of the environment.
Use brute force for every problem.
questions.explanation: Rationality is about doing the 'right thing' (maximizing expected utility), not necessarily being perfect or human-like.

questions.question: How do you represent 'All dogs have tails' in First-Order Logic?
questions.explanation: Universal quantification (For all) is usually paired with implication (→).

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Breadth-First Search (BFS)?
questions.explanation: BFS expands all nodes at each level, leading to exponential time complexity O(b^d).

questions.question: Uniform Cost Search (UCS) is equivalent to BFS if:
questions.explanation: If all steps cost the same (e.g., 1), searching by lowest path cost is identical to searching by shallowest depth.

questions.question: Alpha-Beta Pruning is used to:
options: Change the outcome of the Minimax algorithm.
Reduce the number of nodes evaluated in Minimax without changing the result.
Increase the depth of the search tree indefinitely.
Convert a game tree into a graph.
questions.explanation: It prunes branches that cannot influence the final decision, optimizing speed but not changing the Minimax result.

questions.question: Unsupervised Learning deals with:
questions.explanation: Unsupervised learning finds patterns in data that has no pre-existing labels.

questions.question: In CSP, the 'Minimum Remaining Values' (MRV) heuristic selects:
options: The variable with the largest domain.
The variable with the fewest legal values remaining.
The value that constraints the fewest neighbors.
questions.explanation: Also known as 'Fail First', it picks the variable most likely to cause a failure soon.

questions.question: Which selection method in Genetic Algorithms selects individuals with probability proportional to their fitness?
questions.explanation: Roulette Wheel Selection allocates a slice of the wheel proportional to fitness.

questions.question: John Searle's 'Chinese Room Argument' attempts to refute:
questions.explanation: Searle argues that syntax (manipulating symbols) does not equal semantics (understanding), thus challenging Strong AI.

questions.question: Hill Climbing is often susceptible to getting stuck in:
questions.explanation: Hill climbing is a greedy local search that can get stuck on a peak that is not the highest point (Local Maxima).

questions.question: For a 'Medical Diagnosis System', the Performance Measure (P in PEAS) would likely be:
options: Healthy patient, minimized cost, correct diagnosis
questions.explanation: Performance is the metric of success: curing the patient and accurate diagnosis.

questions.question: Greedy Best-First Search expands nodes based on:
questions.explanation: Greedy search only looks at the heuristic h(n) (closeness to goal), ignoring path cost g(n).

questions.question: Which of the following is an Ensemble Learning method?
questions.explanation: Random Forest is an ensemble of multiple Decision Trees.

questions.question: Tokenization in NLP refers to:
options: Splitting text into individual words or units.
questions.explanation: Tokenization breaks a stream of text into words, phrases, symbols, or other meaningful elements (tokens).

questions.question: In a Zero-Sum game:
options: The sum of all payoffs is always 100.
One player's gain is exactly the other player's loss.
questions.explanation: The utility values of the players sum to zero (e.g., +1 vs -1).

questions.question: What is 'Segmentation' in Image Processing?
options: Reducing the size of the image.
Partitioning an image into multiple segments (sets of pixels).
Blurring the image to remove noise.
Converting color images to black and white.
questions.explanation: Segmentation groups pixels to locate objects or boundaries.

questions.question: Modus Ponens is a rule of inference that states:
options: If P implies Q, and Q is true, then P is true.
If P implies Q, and P is true, then Q is true.
If P implies Q, and not Q, then not P.
If P or Q is true, and not P, then Q.
questions.explanation: P -> Q, P, therefore Q.

questions.question: Overfitting occurs when a model:
options: Is too simple to capture the data structure.
Learns the noise in the training data rather than the signal.
Performs well on test data but poorly on training data.
questions.explanation: Overfitting means the model fits the training data too closely, failing to generalize to new data.

questions.question: What is the purpose of an Activation Function in a Neural Network?
options: To introduce non-linearity into the model.
questions.explanation: Without non-linear activation functions, a Neural Network is just a linear regression model.

questions.question: The 'State List' in a Backtracking algorithm contains:
options: The nodes in the current path being explored.
questions.explanation: In backtracking (DFS), the state list tracks the current branch from root to leaf.

questions.question: Weak AI is defined as:
options: AI that simulates intelligence for a specific task but doesn't have a mind.
AI that is smarter than humans in every way.
questions.explanation: Weak AI acts *as if* it is intelligent within a domain, without claiming sentience.

questions.question: A Simple Reflex Agent selects actions based on:
questions.explanation: Simple Reflex Agents use Condition-Action rules on the *current* percept, ignoring history.

questions.question: As a Genetic Algorithm converges, the population diversity:
questions.explanation: Convergence implies the population is settling on a fitness peak, so individuals become very similar.

questions.question: Bidirectional Search is feasible in Chess.
questions.explanation: False. Bidirectional search requires searching backward from the goal. In Chess, there are millions of possible 'Checkmate' goal states, making backward search impossible.

questions.question: Which of the following is a core component of an Expert System?
questions.explanation: Expert Systems consist of a Knowledge Base and an Inference Engine.

questions.question: Which search algorithm uses a Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) data structure?
questions.explanation: DFS uses a Stack (LIFO).

questions.question: Which metric is commonly used to evaluate a Classification model?
questions.explanation: A Confusion Matrix shows True Positives, False Positives, etc.

questions.question: Propositional Logic uses:
options: True/False symbols and Connectives (AND, OR, NOT).
questions.explanation: Propositional logic deals with atomic facts and connectives, unlike First-Order logic which adds quantifiers.

questions.question: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) is an example of:
questions.explanation: KNN is a lazy learner because it does not build a model during training; it waits until a query is made to compute distances.

questions.question: The 'Chinese Room' thought experiment was proposed by:
questions.explanation: John Searle proposed it to argue against Strong AI.

questions.question: A* search is equivalent to Uniform Cost Search if:
questions.explanation: If the heuristic is zero, A* ($f = g + h$) becomes ($f = g$), which is Uniform Cost Search.

questions.question: Which values are assigned to Alpha and Beta initially in Alpha-Beta Pruning?
questions.explanation: Alpha starts at worst case for Max (-Inf), Beta starts at worst case for Min (+Inf).

questions.question: A system that filters emails into 'Spam' or 'Not Spam' is performing:
questions.explanation: It is assigning data to discrete categories (Classes).

questions.question: Consistency of a heuristic h(n) implies:
questions.explanation: Consistency is a stronger condition than admissibility. If a heuristic is consistent, it is automatically admissible.

questions.question: Arthur Samuel is famous for writing a program that played which game?
questions.explanation: Arthur Samuel wrote the first significant Checkers playing program which learned from experience.

questions.question: Data Normalization is the process of:
options: Scaling data to a specific range (e.g., 0 to 1).
questions.explanation: Normalization scales features so that they contribute equally to distance calculations.

questions.question: Which algorithm is commonly used to solve Constraint Satisfaction Problems (CSPs)?
questions.explanation: Backtracking is the standard approach for CSPs (like N-Queens, Map Coloring).

questions.question: In a Decision Tree, internal nodes represent:
questions.explanation: Internal nodes are tests (e.g., Is Age > 50?), branches are outcomes, leaves are classes.

questions.question: Degrees of Freedom (DOF) in robotics refers to:
options: The battery life of the robot.
The number of independent movements the robot can make.
The processing speed of the robot.
questions.explanation: A joint that allows rotation is 1 DOF. A free-floating object has 6 DOF (3 position, 3 rotation).

questions.question: Cognitive Science connects AI with which field?
questions.explanation: Cognitive Science studies the mind and intelligence, bridging AI with how the human brain works.
